questions.text: Which among the following is not a characteristic feature of the ileum compared to the jejunum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The jejunum is wider and thicker than the ileum.
  • The proximal 40% of the small intestine is referred to as the jejunum; the remainder is the ileum.
  • There is no clear demarcation between the jejunum and the ileum, but the small bowel does change gradually in character from proximal to distal.
  • The jejunum tends to have a wider diameter and a thicker wall, with more prominent mucosal folds (valvulae conniventes), while the ileum has a thicker, more fatty mesentery with ;more complex arterial arcades. (Option A & B)
  • The ileum also contains larger aggregates of lymph nodes (Peyer's patches), which can occasionally become lead points in intussusception in childhood. (Option D)

questions.text: Which artery is the main blood supply of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The small intestine has a very rich blood supply, derived from the superior mesenteric artery, while venous drainage is via the portal venous system, into which the superior mesenteric vein drains blood rich in nutrients after a meal.
  • This arrangement facilitates the processing of nutrients by the liver, into which the portal vein drains in turn.
  • The lymphatic drainage of the small intestine follows the arterial supply.

Coeliac trunk (Option A) can be ruled out because it supplies the foregut structures, such as the stomach, liver, spleen, and proximal duodenum, but not the majority of the small intestine.

The inferior mesenteric artery (Option B) supplies the hindgut, including the distal third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum, and therefore does not contribute to the small intestine's blood supply.

The gastroduodenal artery (Option) supplies parts of the stomach, proximal duodenum, and pancreas, but has a very limited role in supplying the small intestine overall.

questions.text: Which among the following is principally absorbed by the terminal ileum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bile salt and vitamin B12 are principally absorbed by the terminal ileum.

Functions and Physiology of the Small Intestine Key Points

Primary Functions

  • Digestion of food
  • Absorption of nutrients, water, and electrolytes

Digestion of Nutrients

  • Carbohydrates and proteins:
    • Initially broken down by pancreatic enzymes in the intestinal lumen
    • Final hydrolysis occurs at the brush border of the jejunum
    • Absorbed after brush border digestion
  • Fats:
    • Digested by pancreatic lipase and bile salts
    • Fatty acids and monoglycerides separate from bile salts in the jejunum and are absorbed
    • Transported into circulation via the lymphatic system
  • Site-Specific Absorption
    • Jejunum:
      • Principal site for absorption of:
      • Fluid
      • Electrolytes
      • Iron (Option A, B & C)
      • Folate
      • Fat
      • Protein
      • Carbohydrates
  • Terminal ileum:
    • Specific absorption of:
      • Bile salts
      • Vitamin B12
    • Contains specialized transporters for these substances

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true for abdominal typhoid infections?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The drug of choice for typhoid infection is chloramphenicol.

  • Typhoid fever is caused by typhi and presents with fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10-20 days.
  • Over the next week, the patient can develop distension, diarrhoea, splenomegaly, and characteristic 'rose spots' on the abdomen caused by a vasculitis.
  • Typhoid is a systemic infection, and the diagnosis of typhoid is confirmed by culture of blood or stool.
  • Treatment is with antibiotics, usually chloramphenicol.
  • Several surgical complications can result, including paralytic ileus, intestinal haemorrhage, free ileal perforation, and cholecystitis.
  • Perforation of a typhoid ulcer characteristically occurs during the third week of the illness, although it is sometimes the first clinical sign of the disease.
  • The ulcer is parallel to the long axis of the gut and is usually situated in the distal ileum. Perforation requires surgery to wash out and close the ulcer and intestinal resection is usually avoided. In unstable patients, notably with evidence of septic shock, the bowel should be exteriorized and the perforation closed after recovery.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella enterica and presents with fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10-20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop distension, diarrhoea, splenomegaly and characteristic 'rose spots' on the abdomen caused by a vasculitis. Typhoid is a systemic infection and diagnosis of typhoid is confirmed by culture of blood or stool. Treatment is by antibiotics, usually chloramphenicol. A number of surgical complications can result, including paralytic ileus, intestinal haemorrhage, free ileal perforation and cholecystitis.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a principle of management of enterocutaneous fistula?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Physiologic assessment is not a principle of management of enterocutaneous fistula.

Key Management Principles

  • Infection Control (Option A)
    • CT scan to identify collections
    • Drain abscesses when present
  • Skin Protection
    • Crucial due to the caustic nature of small bowel effluent
  • Nutritional Support (Option B)
    • Replace fluid and electrolyte losses (especially in proximal/high-output fistulas)
    • Provide macronutrients (carbs, protein, fat) and vitamins
    • Feeding route:
      • Enteral feeding is preferred if feasible
      • Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) if the fistula is proximal or high-output
  • Imaging and Planning
    • Coordinate with the radiologist
    • Use contrast studies to define anatomy:\
      • Small bowel follow-through
      • Fistulogram
      • Contrast enema
  • Surgical Considerations (Option D)
    • Avoid anastomosis if:
      • Ongoing intra-abdominal sepsis
      • Hypoalbuminaemia (<32 g/L)
    • Surgery can be technically complex; proper planning is essential

questions.text: What is the threshold for a high-output fistula in an enterocutaneous fistula?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The threshold for a high-output fistula in an enterocutaneous fistula is >500 ml/day.

Enterocutaneous fistula

Definition

  • An abnormal connection between the small intestine and the skin.
  • Causes
    • Most common:
      • Surgical complications, such as:
        • Leak from an anastomosis
        • Inadvertent enterotomy during dissection
  • Other causes:
    • Fistulating Crohn's disease (CD)
    • Radiotherapy
    • Abdominal trauma
  • Management Overview
    • Challenges: Particularly difficult if high-output (>500 mL/day)
    • Healing
      • Most ECFs heal spontaneously if:
        • No distal obstruction
        • No active disease at the fistula site
    • Delayed healing occurs if:
      • Persistent epithelial tract
      • Complex abscess present

questions.text: Which among the following is not a cause of short bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intestinal tuberculosis is not a cause of short bowel syndrome.

Short Bowel Syndrome (SBS)

Definition

  • A condition of intractable diarrhoea and malabsorption following significant resection or bypass of the small intestine, leading to progressive malnutrition.

Causes

  • Most common:
    • Crohn's disease and its surgical complications (~50% of cases) (Option B)
  • Other causes:
    • Mesenteric vascular thrombosis (Option A)
    • Radiation enteritis (Option D)
    • Intestinal tumours

Pathophysiology

  • SBS symptoms typically occur when <200 cm of the small intestine remains.
  • However, both the length and the functional capacity of the remaining bowel matter.
  • Distal small bowel (ileum):
    • Has tight intercellular junctions → better fluid absorption
    • Can adapt to assume jejunal functions, but the reverse is limited
  • Loss of the ileocaecal valve:
    • Previously thought important, but significance likely relates more to preservation of the distal ileum and right colon

Surgical Considerations

  • Procedures aiming to:
    • Increase surface area
    • Slow intestinal transit
    • It has shown some benefit in children
    • Role in adults remains unclear
  • Intestinal Failure
    • Defined as the inability to maintain adequate hydration or nutrition without intravenous support (fluids, electrolytes, or nutrients)
    • Parenteral nutrition (PN) is the mainstay of treatment

Advanced Management

  • Complications of long-term PN:
    • Loss of venous access
    • Progressive liver dysfunction
  • These may necessitate small bowel transplantation
  • Outcomes improving:
    • 5-year survival >80% in some centres

questions.text: Which among the following is not a complication of home parenteral nutrition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteoporosis is not a complication of home parenteral nutrition, although it can lead to bone conditions like osteomalacia.

Short bowel syndrome (SBS) occurs when there is insufficient functional small intestine to maintain adequate digestion and absorption, typically after surgical resection. It often presents with malnutrition, diarrhoea, and fluid/electrolyte imbalance.

  • The most common causes include:
    • Crohn's disease (nearly 50% of cases)
    • Mesenteric vascular thrombosis
    • Radiation enteritis
    • Intestinal tumours
  • Symptoms usually manifest when <200 cm of small bowel
  • However, the functional capacity of the remnant bowel is also crucial.
  • The ileum is better able to adapt than the jejunum, and the presence of the distal ileum and right colon is more important than the ileocaecal valve itself for preserving absorption.

Management:

  • The mainstay of treatment for SBS is home parenteral nutrition (HPN), which allows patients to maintain fluid and nutritional homeostasis and achieve a reasonably good quality of life.
  • While interest exists in pharmacologic agents that promote intestinal adaptation (e.g., growth hormone, glutamine, GLP-2 agonists), these are adjuncts and not primary therapies.

Complications of HPN:

  • While life-sustaining, HPN is expensive and associated with several complications, including:
    • Catheter-related complications:
      • Catheter-related sepsis
      • Catheter occlusion
    • Metabolic complications:
      • Fibrotic liver disease
      • Gallstones
      • Metabolic bone disease (a broad term encompassing various bone disorders due to metabolic imbalance, such as osteomalacia or reduced bone density)

questions.text: Which nutrient deficiency is most common in short bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Patients with an intact colon are relatively protected from the effects of massive small bowel resection because of the ability of the colon to absorb not only fluid and electrolytes, but a modest amount of nutrient energy.
  • Patients with as little as 100-200 cm of jejunum anastomosed to an intact colon may therefore be able to maintain satisfactory macronutrient, fluid, and electrolyte status, although they will, of course, be at risk of fat-soluble and B12 vitamin deficiencies and will also generally need oral nutritional supplements of trace elements, vitamins, and minerals.

Vitamin C (Option A) is absorbed in the proximal small intestine (duodenum and proximal jejunum), which is often preserved in SBS, so deficiency is uncommon.

Iron (Option B) is also absorbed in the proximal small intestine, and while iron deficiency can occur, it is not as common or specific as vitamin B12 deficiency in SBS.

Carbohydrates (Option D) are primarily absorbed in the jejunum, and the ileum can adapt to take over some of this function if the jejunum is resected. Therefore, carbohydrate deficiency is rare in SBS.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false for Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A Meckel's diverticulum is present on the antimesenteric side of the intestine.

Meckel's diverticulum

  • A Meckel's diverticulum is a persistent remnant of the vitellointestinal duct and is present in about 2% of the population. (Option A)
  • It is found on the antimesenteric side of the ileum, commonly approximately 60 cm from the ileocaecal valve, and is classically 5 cm long. (Option C)
  • A Meckel's diverticulum is congenital.
  • It contains all three coats of the bowel wall and has its blood supply.
  • It may be vulnerable to obstruction and inflammation in the same way as the appendix; indeed, when a normal appendix is found at surgery for suspected appendicitis, a Meckel's diverticulum should be looked for by examining the small bowel, particularly if free fluid or pus is found.
  • In approximately 20% of cases, the mucosa of a Meckel's diverticulum contains heterotopic epithelium of gastric, colonic, or pancreatic type. (Option D)

questions.text: Which among the following is not the most commonly affected site of abdominal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The jejunum is not usually affected by intestinal TB.

  • Tuberculosis, like Crohn's disease, can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus.
  • The sites affected most often are the ileum, proximal colon, and peritoneum. (Option A, B, & D)
  • There are two principal disease presentations.
  • Cause: Secondary to pulmonary TB due to swallowing of tubercle bacilli.
  • Common Site: Terminal ileum, with transverse ulcers and thickened, inflamed serosa covered in tubercles.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Diarrhoea
    • Weight loss
    • May present with subacute obstruction, perforation, or fistula
  • Imaging Findings:
    • Barium follow-through or CT may show non-filling of the terminal ileum, caecum, and ascending colon due to segmental narrowing.
  • Treatment:
    • Antituberculous chemotherapy is usually effective if pulmonary TB is also treated.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Reserved for complications like perforation or complete obstruction.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for haemorrhagic Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A Technetium-99 scan can detect the presence of ectopic gastric mucosa that might not be detected by endoscopy, and hence is the investigation of choice.

Meckel's Diverticulum

  • A congenital remnant of the vitellointestinal duct.
  • Often contains heterotopic mucosa (e.g., gastric or pancreatic), which may predispose to peptic ulceration and bleeding.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic and difficult to detect on contrast studies.

Clinical Presentations

  • Haemorrhage
    • Caused by peptic ulceration from ectopic gastric mucosa.
    • Presents as painless rectal bleeding or melaena.
    • If upper and lower endoscopy are negative, a Tc-99m scan can detect ectopic gastric mucosa in the diverticulum.
  • Diverticulitis
    • Mimics appendicitis; if perforated, may resemble a perforated duodenal ulcer.
  • Intussusception
    • Meckel's can act as a lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.
  • Chronic Ulceration
    • Causes umbilical pain, reflecting its midgut origin.
  • Intestinal Obstruction
    • Due to a fibrous band between the diverticulum and the umbilicus.
    • It may also cause volvulus around the band.
  • Perforation
    • Rare, but can occur in the setting of diverticulitis or ulceration.

Management

  • Incidental findings:
    • Leave alone if the diverticulum has a wide mouth and a normal appearance.
    • Consider resection if thickened or narrow-necked.
  • Littre's hernia:
    • When Meckel's is found within an inguinal or femoral hernia.

Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) (Option A) abdomen can help identify complications like inflammation, perforation, or obstruction, but it cannot reliably detect ectopic gastric mucosa, making it unsuitable for identifying the source of bleeding in Meckel's diverticulum.

MRI abdomen (option B) offers excellent soft tissue resolution, but is not used in the evaluation of gastrointestinal bleeding, nor is it capable of detecting ectopic mucosa, so it is not appropriate in this context.

Ultrasound abdomen (Option D) helps identify intestinal obstruction or intussusception, but Meckel's diverticulum itself is often missed on ultrasound, and it cannot detect mucosal abnormalities, making it inadequate for investigating bleeding.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false for the hyperplastic type of abdominal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyperplastic intestinal tuberculosis occurs as a result of ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not bovis.

Hyperplastic Intestinal Tuberculosis

  • Cause: Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in individuals with high resistance.
  • Common Site: Ileocecal region, though distal ileal lesions may occur. (Option B)

Pathology:

  • Infection localizes in lymphoid follicles.
  • Leads to chronic inflammation, intestinal wall thickening, and luminal narrowing.
  • Regional lymph nodes are involved early and may caseate.
  • Unlike Crohn's disease, abscess and fistula formation are rare.

Clinical Features

  • Abdominal pain with intermittent diarrhoea (option D)
  • Incomplete ileal obstruction → stasis, bacterial overgrowth (Option C)
    • Causes steatorrhoea, anaemia, and weight loss
  • Possible right iliac fossa mass and general malaise

Investigations:

  • Barium follow-through/small bowel enema:
  • Shows a long, narrow terminal ileal segment
  • CT scan:
    • Reveals segmental narrowing, proximal dilatation, and lymphadenopathy

Management

  • Antitubercular chemotherapy is first-line if the diagnosis is clear and no obstruction is present.
  • Ileocecal resection may be needed in cases of:
    • Obstruction
    • Diagnostic uncertainty (to differentiate from CD or lymphoma)

It is an autosomal recessive disease
Causes melanosis of the mouth and lips

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false for Peutz-Jegher's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease.

Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS)

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Features:
    • Melanin pigmentation of the lips, mouth, digits, and perianal skin (Option C)
    • Multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small bowel and colon (Option D)
  • Genetics: Associated with the STK11 gene mutation on chromosome 19 (Option A)

Complications

  • Polyps may cause intestinal obstruction, intussusception, or bleeding
  • Malignant transformation of the polyps is rare, but patients have an increased overall cancer risk (e.g., gastrointestinal, breast, gynecologic cancers)
  • Long-term studies show reduced survival due to bowel complications and malignancy

Management

  • Routine surveillance:
    • Regular colonic screening
    • Breast and cervical screening for women
  • Polyp removal only if symptomatic:
    • For recurrent bleeding, obstruction, or intussusception
    • Techniques: Enterotomy, snaring via colonoscope, or segmental resection if disease is extensive

questions.text: Which among the following is not a type of small bowel malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Squamous cell carcinomas are not seen in the small bowel.

  • Small bowel malignancy is rare and classically presents late, most often diagnosed after surgery for small bowel obstruction.
  • Four types will be considered, which account for over 99% of small bowel malignancies:
    • Adenocarcinoma (Option A)
    • Carcinoid tumours (Option B)
    • Lymphomas
    • Mesenchymal tumours (gastrointestinal stromal tumours [GIST]) (Option D)

questions.text: A male patient with carcinoid syndrome presents to the hospital. Which among the following is not a feature of carcinoid syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bronchodilatation is not a feature of carcinoid syndrome.

  • Carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours found most commonly in the appendix, followed by the ileum and rectum.
  • They arise from Kulchitsky cells located at the base of the crypts of Lieberkühn.
  • Appendicular carcinoids are often found incidentally during appendicectomy (in ~2% of cases).
  • Tumours can cause fibrosis in surrounding tissues, leading to bowel and mesenteric distortion, with characteristic imaging appearances.
  • These tumours produce vasoactive substances, most commonly:
    • Serotonin (5-HT)
    • Histamine
    • Prostaglandins
    • Kallikrein
  • When they metastasise to the liver, the secreted substances bypass liver metabolism, leading to carcinoid syndrome.
  • Carcinoid syndrome features:
    • Flushing (often triggered by alcohol) (Option D)
    • Reddish-blue cyanosis
    • Diarrhoea (Option A)
    • Borborygmi
    • Asthmatic attacks
    • Tricuspid and pulmonary valve stenosis (Option C)
  • Surgical resection is the primary treatment for localised disease, though recurrence can occur.
  • Octreotide scanning is useful preoperatively to detect both primary and metastatic tumours.
  • Chromogranin A is a useful tumour marker for monitoring disease burden and recurrence.
  • Liver resection may be considered in selected patients with hepatic metastases.
  • Octreotide (somatostatin analogue) helps control symptoms and is used perioperatively to prevent carcinoid crisis.
  • Carcinoid tumours are not usually responsive to chemotherapy or radiotherapy.
